content:
I think a big part of it is that the "spiritual guru" has a sort of schtick that people cultivate and look for commercially. In contrast, self-realization as a phenomenon is the same thing a lot of historical religious figures tried to communicate before getting either killed or put on a pedestal and turned into a belief system. You really just become the completely authentic version of what you naturally are, so the sort of whimsical soft-spoken people fit the mold of guru, and the more forceful types end up with followings/communes/cults/religions. The vast majority of people who are self-realized are likely just very regular people who are like "well, feel a lot better now, anyway" and just continue with a very regular life.  

There's also unfortunately a sort of automatic feedback loop in communication, whereby if you spend a lot of time talking to and cultivating a certain type of audience, you naturally want to lean into their perceived image of you to make them happy.
